title: 110_s1065
content: The "Heroes at Home Act of 2007" requires the assessment and documentation of cognitive functioning for deployed members of the Armed Forces. The Secretary of Defense must establish a protocol for assessing cognitive functioning of Armed Forces members before and after deployment in Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom. This includes diagnosing traumatic brain injury and post-traumatic stress disorder. The Secretary may use the protocol for other purposes as deemed appropriate. The protocol includes administering neurocognitive assessments to Armed Forces members before and after deployment in Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom. The assessments must be computer-based and can be developed using existing commercial products or new methods. The assessments required for Armed Forces members before and after deployment must have the same format. The Secretary is prohibited from using assessment results to determine deployment readiness. Medical data on cognitive functioning obtained from assessments must be made available to combat medics and other Department of Defense personnel. The Secretary of Defense is authorized to provide medical services to Armed Forces members and entities as deemed appropriate. A report on the implementation of this section must be submitted to Congress within one year of enactment. Appropriations of $3,750,000 for fiscal year 2008 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2009 through 2012 are authorized for this purpose. Training and certification program for family caregiver personal care attendants for veterans and members of the armed forces with traumatic brain injury. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish a program for training and certifying family caregivers of veterans and members of the Armed Forces with traumatic brain injury as personal care attendants. The program will be located in Tier I polytrauma centers of the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, in collaboration with the Secretary of Defense, will develop training curricula incorporating standards and protocols from national brain injury care specialist organizations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will utilize existing curricula to develop training programs for family caregivers of veterans and members of the Armed Forces with traumatic brain injury. Participation eligibility will be determined based on the clinical needs of the veteran or member of the Armed Forces. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will provide training programs for family caregivers of veterans and members of the Armed Forces with traumatic brain injury. Family caregivers who receive certification as personal care attendants will be eligible for compensation. Costs of training for family members of veterans will be covered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, while costs for family members of members of the Armed Forces will be reimbursed by the Secretary of Defense. The program provides training for family caregivers of veterans and Armed Forces members with traumatic brain injury. Reimbursement for personal care attendants will be covered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for veterans' family members and by the Secretary of Defense for Armed Forces members' family members. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs cannot deny reimbursement for health care services to a veteran with a brain injury based on the personal care attendant not being a family member. SEC. 4. TELEHEALTH AND TELEMENTAL HEALTH SERVICES OF THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE AND THE DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish a telehealth demonstration project to assess cognitive functioning of military members with head trauma. The project will improve diagnosis and treatment of traumatic brain injury at selected locations, with priority given to rural areas. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will prioritize rural areas for a telehealth demonstration project to assess cognitive functioning of military members with head trauma. The project will use telehealth technology to gather information on brain injuries and symptoms of traumatic brain injury. The use of telehealth technology for rehabilitating and educating military members and veterans with traumatic brain injury, following national standards and protocols for assessment and care. The demonstration project for rehabilitating and educating military members and veterans with traumatic brain injury shall incorporate telemental health technology proven effective in diagnosis and treatment. It will be administered under a joint incentives program and in accordance with specific legislation. The demonstration project for rehabilitating and educating military members and veterans with traumatic brain injury will be funded through the DOD-VA Health Care Sharing Incentive Fund. A joint report on the project must be submitted to Congress by the Secretaries of Defense and Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs are required to conduct an ongoing study on telehealth and telemental health services for members and former members of the Armed Forces. The ongoing study on telehealth and telemental health services for members of the Armed Forces includes assessing utilization by National Guard and Reserves, improving integration with clinical medicine, and evaluating provision in rural settings and community-based clinics. The ongoing study on telehealth and telemental health services for members of the Armed Forces includes assessing utilization by National Guard and Reserves, improving integration with clinical medicine, and evaluating provision in rural settings and community-based clinics. Additionally, the feasibility and advisability of partnering with civilian mental health facilities to provide telehealth and telemental health services to members and former members of the Armed Forces will be explored in annual reports by the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs must jointly submit an annual report to Congress on the findings of the Joint Executive Counsel regarding telehealth and telemental health services for members of the Armed Forces. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions are provided for terms such as "national brain injury care specialist organization," "neurocognitive," and "traumatic brain injury."
